Pre-Game Insights: USA will hope to do the unthinkable in Florida despite the swamped conditions.
A USA win or a washout takes USA to the super 8 stage, while a loss would leave USA at the mercy of the outcome of the Pakistan and Ireland game.
USA kept India on the leash for the majority of the run chase on Wednesday, showing their strength.
USA look firm favourites over a beleaguered Ireland, who are languishing at the bottom of the table after a thrashing by India and a shock loss against Canada.
The two nations squared off against each other at the same venue in December 2021 and shared the honours one all in a 2 match T20I series.
The track in Fort Lauderdale has been a batsman's paradise, but it will be under covers for more than 72 hours leading up to the game, leading to a soft and damp surface.
USA employed only pace men to deliver all of their 18.2 overs against India, and are expected to go with the same attack in this crunch game.
Andrew Balbirnie, Ireland's man for all seasons, has endured a torrid run in his last 5 outings for Ireland but would be itching to make a mark at the world stage.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The greater Miami area is swamped with as much as 10-12 inches of rain, affecting the match conditions.
The game will be played at Central Broward Park, Fort Lauderdale, Florida.
The match is scheduled for 14 June 2024 at 10.30 AM local time.
Others: USA probable XI: Monank Patel (captain) (wk), Steven Taylor, Andries Gous, Aaron Jones (vice captain), Corey Anderson, Nitish Kumar, Jasdeep Singh, Harmeet Singh, Shadley Van Schalkwyk, Saurabh Netravalkar, Ali Khan.

Ireland probable XI: Paul Stirling (captain), Andrew Balbirnie, Lorcan Tucker (wk), Harry Tector, Curtis Campher, George Dockrell, Benjamin White, Josh Little, Mark Adair, Gareth Delany, Barry McCarthy.

USA batter Steven Taylor on their prospects of qualifying into the Super 8s: 'It'll be a dream come true to go to the next round. Especially the Super Eight would be the first time it's happened as well.'

Irish all-rounder Mark Adair on their qualification chances: 'I think for us our objective is still to qualify for the next round. If that means that we have to go out there and put in a big performance with bat and ball, then so be it.'
